column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Choose Personal Core Values
#Text=Google defines core values as the guiding principles that dictate behavior and action .
#Text=Knowing your personal core values can help you make decisions , reduce stress , and live in alignment with your life choices .
#Text=Identifying these values can be difficult .
#Text=Learn how to choose personal core values that truly represent the qualities you value most in life ; ones that help to guide you in making decisions .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Brainstorm a list of potential values .
#Text=Think about the roles and ideas that are important to you .
#Text=Think about the people with whom you interact ; your mom , dad , friend , mentor or others that may have a special relationship with you .
#Text=Look at how you spend your time .
#Text=You may hang out with friends regularly , or you may spend a lot of energy fighting for a specific cause .
#Text=Examine how you spend your money to discover certain values in yourself .
#Text=Money is another indicator of what you value .
#Text=For example , if you tend to buy a lot of books , you may value knowledge or education .
#Text=If you save money , you may be thrifty .
#Text=Reflect on some of your favorite experiences .
#Text=Identify what you were doing , who you were with , and why it is so memorable .
#Text=Look at a list of values .
#Text=It can be hard to identify your values on your own , as many can seem abstract , like love or kindness .
#Text=After brainstorming the values you identify with , look at a list that provides you with options that you may not have considered .
#Text=Search for different lists online or in books on personal vision or development .
#Text=Choose other values you identify with and relate to .
#Text=Some websites try to put limits on how many core values a person can have .
#Text=Others state that it does not matter how many core values you have , as long as you live your life accordingly .
#Text=Choose between five and seven core values that stand out above the rest .
#Text=This will be the hardest part .
#Text=These will be the values you hold closest and use to guide the decisions you make in your every day life .
#Text=Take your time .
#Text=Rushing this process may make you choose values that do not represent the things closest to your heart .
#Text=Ask others .
#Text=If you are not sure what to choose , ask others that know you well to share with you their opinion on what you value .
#Text=Define each core value .
#Text=First , define each value in your own words .
#Text=For example , identify what " kindness " means to you or describe what having the value of " family " means .

column1: #Text=This will be the definition of what the value means to you .
#Text=Now look each up in the dictionary .
#Text=It will be interesting to see the differences in the definitions .
#Text=Prioritize your core values .
#Text=Some values will stand out to you over others .
#Text=Knowing which you hold in higher regard will help you decide where to spend your time and energy .
#Text=It may also help you work through specific conflicts .
#Text=For example , you may value both achievement and family .
#Text=Holding family in a position of higher importance , you are more likely to spend unscheduled time at home instead of the office .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=Revisit your core values from time to time .
#Text=Values tend to remain pretty constant throughout one 's life .
#Text=There are circumstances or events in life that may cause you to modify your values or how you define them .
